formats.name: micro_mystery
formats.instruction: Invent a tiny mystery. Describe the setup and leave the question unresolved. Aim for suspense. 1-2 sentences.

formats.name: reverse_recipe
formats.instruction: Describe the final result first, then unravel the steps backwards, as if time rewinds. Make it quirky. 80-120 words.

formats.name: contrarian_manifesto
formats.instruction: Write a rebellious mini-manifesto against a common belief. Make it punchy, with a call to arms. 40-70 words.

formats.name: timed_monologue
formats.instruction: Imagine you have 60 seconds to explain an idea to someone. Write your thoughts, no edits, as if you’re racing a clock. 80-110 words.

formats.name: visual_scene
formats.instruction: Paint a vivid picture with words: describe a place, moment, or object so clearly that readers feel they’re there. Avoid opinions. 60-90 words.

formats.name: parallel_worlds
formats.instruction: Imagine an alternate universe where a detail is different. Describe the impact in 2-4 paragraphs. Explore the butterfly effect. 300-500 words.

formats.name: postcard_wisdom
formats.instruction: Write advice as if you’re sending a postcard to a stranger. Be brief, heartfelt, and concrete. 15-40 words.

formats.name: jigsaw_memory
formats.instruction: Recall a memory by describing fragments and how they fit together. Weave in sensory details. 150-230 words.

title_styles: Make the title a riddle or mystery that invites curiosity, e.g.: 'What happened in the silent hallway?'
Write a title as if it's a headline from tomorrow’s news, e.g.: 'Scientists accidentally invent teleportation'
Frame the title as a dare or challenge, e.g.: 'Prove me wrong about X'
Use an evocative, sensory phrase, e.g.: 'The sound of rain on forgotten places'
Title as an overheard quote, e.g.: 'There’s no such thing as a boring Tuesday'
structure_variants: Start with an unexpected fact or statistic, and build your post from there.
Write your post as a series of connected vignettes or snapshots.
Integrate lists or bullet points within the narrative for pacing.
Split your piece into contrasting halves: see both the good and the bad.
Frame your post as an open letter to someone real or imaginary.
